5) Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,
6) Changes since the last Hazard Review (HR) or PHA

8. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Wilbur-Ellis is committed to continuously making safety improvements. To improve the safety of the anhydrous ammonia system, Wilbur-Ellis is in the process of developing a more comprehensive anhydrous ammonia inspection checklist for the bullet tank system and nurse tanks. The comprehensive checklist will include daily, weekly, and annual inspection frequencies, including visual and non destructive tests to evaluate the mechanical integrity of the tanks, valves, piping, etc. At a minimum, inspection frequencies will follow industry standards. Wilbur-Ellis is also implementing a facility-wide comprehensive corrective action/preventative action CAPA) log to track and facilitate completion of listed CAs on a timely basis. Recommended improvements and identified deficiencies from the  inspection checklists, compliance audits, and PHA studies will be included on the facility CAPA log along with the priority, employee responsible, and targeted completion dates.

9. Flammables: Worst Case

The use of flammable materials at Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

10. Flammables: Alternative Release

The use of flammable materials at Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.

Executive Summary

1. Accidental Release Prevention Policies

Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address the requirements of 40 CFR 68 Clean Air Act. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland staff is highly trained and utilize equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while safely storing and distributing anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. 
Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland has a commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage System and the Aqueous Ammonia Storage System. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland is located at 1785 East Beamer St., Woodland, California in the county of Yolo. The primary activity at the Facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.

Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in one 11,000-gallon storage tank (bullet) at the site. A maximum of 12- 1,000 gallon nurse tanks may contain anhydrous ammonia , may be staged at the facility.  The facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia to 82% of the bullet tank and nurse tank capacities. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled and stored in this process is 107,502 pounds.

Aqua ammonia (24% of ammonia by weight) is stored in two 25

,000-gallon above ground tanks at the site. The total quantity of ammonia present in the aqua ammonia, based on 24% active ingredient by weight, is 88,670 pounds. 

3. Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Per 40 CFR 68 Regulations, the description covering the worst-case and alternative case release scenarios has been eliminated from the executive summary. Please refer to the Hazard Assessment report for the results of this analysis. 

-Risk Considerations

Ammonia is a toxic inhalation hazard; and thus, the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks to potentially reach sensitive populations within the community. The facility's identified potential risks for an ammonia release from its process are included in the off-site consequence analysis, Hazard Assessment, and Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). Facility RMP elements and other safety programs are structured to minimize the potential of a release from the identified risks.
   -The history of the Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland (i.e., no CalARP-applicable anhydrous or aqueous ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely storing and distributing anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. 

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program 

As part of the implementation of this Risk Management Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The facility's maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 107,502 lb.  Therefore, the covered process has over the 10,000 lb threshold quantity for EPA RMP and Cal/OSHA PSM.  The 500 lb state threshold for the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program is also exceeded.  As a result, the anhydrou

s ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3 and EPA RMP Program Level 3. 

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:

   -Process Safety Information
   -Process Hazard Analysis
   -Operating Procedures
   -Training
   -Mechanical Integrity
   -Management of Change
   -Pre-Startup Safety Review
   -Compliance Audits
   -Incident Investigation
   -Employee Participation
   -Hot Work Permit
   -Contractors

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.

The facility's maximum storage of aqueous ammonia is 88,670 lb in the aqueous solution.  Therefore, it is over the 20,000 lbs threshold (20% or greater concentration) for EPA RMP and the 500 lbs (all concentrations) state threshold for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland is not subject to Cal/OSHA PSM or Program 3 requirement due to the fact that the concentration of aqueous ammonia managed at the Facility is 24% and the Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantity of aqueous ammonia is only for concentrations greater than 44%. For the reasons mentioned above, the Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank is subject to CalARP Program Level 2 and EPA RMP Program Level 2.

The Aqueous Ammonia Prevention Program 2 elements include:

   -Safety Information
   -Hazard Review
   -Operating Procedures
   -Training
   -Maintenance
   -Compliance Audits
   -Incident Investigation

5. Five-Year Accident History

There have been no EPA-applicable releases of ammonia at Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland in the past five years.

6. Emergency Response Program

Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland is not a First Responder.  Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Woodland has filed a Business Emergency Plan to

help coordinate with local responders.
An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 §3220 is in place.

7. External Events Analysis Information

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted:  

-The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  
   
   The Facility's 2009 PHA is in the process of being reviewed and updated. Section 8.a. of this RMP will be corrected when the PHA review and updates are completed (targeted completion by 6/30/2014. During the June 2009 PHA a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of anhydrous or aqueous ammonia were addressed.  The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact. 

-The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.
   
   A safety walk-down was performed June 4th, 2009.  All findings are documented in the Process Hazard Analysis report.

   The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.

-For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply 

1) The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;
2) Major hazards identified;
3) Process
